texts.definition: Things received in games which are perceived as positive.
markups: <style="Definition">Things received in games which are perceived as positive.</style>

Players typically need some type of encouragement to engage in gameplay. <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> provide one type of encouragement which is tied to changes in the game state or game progression.

Practically all <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Games">Games</link></style> provide some type of <style="CurrentLink">Reward</style>, be it that they are winnable, they give scores or other things to recognize players' actions or give them positive experiences.

<style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> are typically given out to players to indicate they have achieved something worthwhile. This can be that they have completed some part of a game with <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> — for example a <style="Link"><link="quests">Quest</link></style> — or have proven some kind of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. They may also be added to balance <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style> situations, motivate continues engagement where <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Red%20Queen%20Dilemmas">Red Queen Dilemmas</link></style> exist, or to cause <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="player-defined-goals">Player-Defined Goals</link></style> can let players choose with <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> should be available to them.

More specific reasons can be that one has gained <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, won <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style> contests, or found <style="Link"><link="secret-areas">Secret Areas</link></style>. Gaining <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> or engaging in <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> may be its own <style="CurrentLink">Reward</style> but can be strengthened by other <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style>; the same goes for <style="Link"><link="player-killing">Player Killing</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="repeat-combos">Repeat Combos</link></style> (the latter which can be recreate through combining <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> and <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>). Favorable results of <style="Link"><link="betting">Betting</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> are <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> as is <style="Link"><link="delayed-reciprocity">Delayed Reciprocity</link></style> when it occurs. Related to <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can be the result of <style="Link"><link="arithmetic-progression">Arithmetic Progression</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="geometric-progression">Geometric Progression</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Discontinuous%20Progression">Discontinuous Progression</link></style> of player effort in comparison to the size of the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style>. Completing <style="Link"><link="minigames">Minigames</link></style> typically provide <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> unless they are only meant to be truly optional activities. Further, <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can also be used to recognize that players have complied with the fact that <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style> by behaving appropriately. Finally, they can be used to motivate players to perform activities which otherwise would not give gameplay progression, e.g. <style="Link"><link="invites">Invites</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="grinding">Grinding</link></style>.

Most <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can be given out as <style="Link"><link="individual-rewards">Individual Rewards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style> when they finally are given out. They can also be modulated by being the effects of <style="Link"><link="mutual-goals">Mutual Goals</link></style> between players (even in the case when they are not <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style>) or by being the effects of <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> - which in the latter case modulate the use of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> (and <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style>) by threatening with <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> as soon as the player fails some action while waiting with <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> until some additional requirement is met. They can also be applied to <style="Link"><link="shared-resources">Shared Resources</link></style>, potentially letting other players take advantage of them (and becoming <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style>). A somewhat exotic option is to provide players with <style="Link"><link="unknown-goals">Unknown Goals</link></style> but let them know what the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> are; another way to combine these patterns is simply that the much more common version of letting players have hidden goals for winning a game that other players don't know. <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> for things done within certain <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> is one way to create <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>.

There is a wide variety of what <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> actually can consist of. Four different types of categories of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> are <style="Link"><link="access-rewards">Access Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="social-rewards">Social Rewards</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="sustenance-rewards">Sustenance Rewards</link></style> but <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can of course be combined to provide several of these at the same time. Providing <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> are common parts of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> (especially for <style="Link"><link="access-rewards">Access Rewards</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="facilitating-rewards">Facilitating Rewards</link></style>); being able to do <style="Link"><link="game-time-manipulation">Game Time Manipulation</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> is one such possible example. Gaining <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Experience%20Points">Experience Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Money">Money</link></style> are also often part of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> (and may be a <style="Link"><link="sustenance-rewards">Sustenance Reward</link></style>). Another very common type of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> the combination of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Money">Money</link></style> in the form of <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style>; improvements of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> is another form of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> when they are modified rather than given. Other, less common, <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> include receiving <style="Link"><link="extra-chances">Extra Chances</link></style> (for example in the form of <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>) or <style="Link"><link="fudged-results">Fudged Results</link></style>, gaining new <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style>, having <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> increased or removed, gaining entry or higher ranks in <style="Link"><link="factions">Factions</link></style>, being presented with the possibility of <style="Link"><link="quick-returns">Quick Returns</link></style>, and being given access to <style="Link"><link="quick-travel">Quick Travel</link></style> (the three last are <style="Link"><link="access-rewards">Access Rewards</link></style>). Most of these can take be described as being <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> for <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> as much as players, so <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> tends to be a form of <style="CurrentLink">Reward</style> although losing <style="Link"><link="abilities">Abilities</link></style>, etc. are also a form of <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="free-gift-inventories">Free Gift Inventories</link></style> shows how <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can let players help other players but not directly themselves as a consequence of receiving <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style>. Most types of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can actually be split in two halves, <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style> the ability to receive or choose them and actually getting them. In this way, <style="Link"><link="unlocking">Unlocking</link></style> shows how a <style="CurrentLink">Reward</style> does not have to be an improvement directly related to players' gameplay but can also be the potential to improve it. <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> goes on step further and shows that <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can be heavily dependent on game states and player actions without having to affect the game state when players gain them. The existences of <style="Link"><link="goal-achievements">Goal Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="grind-achievements">Grind Achievements</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="handicap-achievements">Handicap Achievements</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="testing-achievements">Testing Achievements</link></style> show how different types of actions can be rewarded. Finally, <style="Link"><link="illusionary-rewards">Illusionary Rewards</link></style> are misperceptions that things are <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> that aren't.

Besides general categories of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> such as what types of goals or what type of progression they depend on, <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can be modified in a great number of different ways. First, <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> can be used to bring uncertainty to what the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> exactly consist of. Second, they can be combined with <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> to balance them or make the overall effect more complex (and <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> can in the same way be mitigate to a certain degree by <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style>, so the two patterns can modulate each other). Third, they can have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diminishing%20Returns">Diminishing Returns</link></style> or be <style="Link"><link="increasing-rewards">Increasing Rewards</link></style> to suit balancing needs or the wanted gameplay arc. Fourth, they can be combined with <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style> (typically positive ones). Fifth, they can be affected by <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distributions">Player-Decided Distributions</link></style> - while this perhaps makes most sense when applied to <style="Link"><link="shared-rewards">Shared Rewards</link></style> and only to those sharing the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> one can consider players not receiving the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> having influence one them. Penultimately, <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>, primarily in <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> but also in the beginning or end of game instances or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, can be used to bring extra attention or to tie narration to the handling out of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style>. Finally, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-broadcasting">Extra-Game Broadcasting</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="outcome-indicators">Outcome Indicators</link></style> can be used to modify which players (and others) are informed about the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> and what information they are provided with.

Less commonly, <style="Link"><link="free-gift-inventories">Free Gift Inventories</link></style> can be provided as extra <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> that is not for the players that received the main <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style>.

Besides their effect on gameplay, the design of <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> need to take into consideration if they break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> if this is important to the game design.

Through the use of <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> can be placed spatially in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="reward-widgets">Reward Widgets</link></style>. This can necessitate movement to pick up the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> as well as open up for <style="Link"><link="ninja-looting">Ninja Looting</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> are important in many ways for players to have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style> in games, they can for example provide <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> depending on when they are given and how certain players can be that they will receive them. The presence of them can increase <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> and create <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style> activities, especially if the <style="CurrentLink">Rewards</style> exist as many small separate parts. When players need to wait for them to be accessible they can cause <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style> and when they are only available for short time periods they qualify as <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-events">Ephemeral Events</link></style> (combined with <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> they can be <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>).

Receiving them can indicate that players have succeeded with <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style> goals or <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>, but can also provide them with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Emotional%20Engrossment">Emotional Engrossment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="encouraged-return-visits">Encouraged Return Visits</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ephemeral-events">Ephemeral Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game-Based%20Social%20Statuses">Game-Based Social Statuses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-competence">Gain Competence</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-planned-development">Player-Planned Development</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>
